thread.title: N.B. becomes last province in Canada to make wildlife estimates publicly available
thread.title_full: N.B. becomes last province in Canada to make wildlife estimates publicly available

author: cbc
title: N.B. becomes last province in Canada to make wildlife estimates publicly available

organizations.name: the department of energy and resource development

text:
A policy change by the New Brunswick government will see the estimated number of select wildlife species published online for the first time this year.
Previously, wildlife estimates were not made available to the public.
"The Department of Energy and Resource Development will publish population estimates for deer, moose and bear in the 2016 Big Game Harvest Report," wrote government spokesperson Jean Bertin in an email. "(It) will be posted to the department's website in summer 2017."
In 2016, CBC News had requested estimates for 11 species in the province from what was then the Department of Natural Resources.
Whitetail deer population estimates will be made available online this summer in the province's 'Big Game Harvest Report.' The figures show that in the last 30 years, the deer population has been reduced by 70 percent. (Shane Fowler/CBC)
The response was that those numbers were not publicly available, making New Brunswick unique among the Canadian provinces.
"This is the first time this question has been asked to me and it is a good question," said Denis Landry, who was Minister of Natural Resources in April 2016. "We're not hiding anything. I'm not sure as to why they are not public."
A Right to Information Request filed by CBC News obtained the estimates of five species, including that of whitetail deer.
An investigation revealed the whitetail deer population had plummeted 70 percent over 30 years.
Biologists have argued that making the information accessible will give the public a better understanding of the welfare of the animals in New Brunswick's forests.
Moose will be one of three species for which the estimated breeding population will be published online this summer. (CBC News)
Estimates for New Brunswick's 'Big Three' species — black bear, moose, and whitetail deer, the most commonly hunted — will be published first. Bobcats and fishers are two species government also tracks, but there is no word yet on when, or if, those estimates will be made public.
As of 2015, there are an estimated 2,000 to 2,500 bobcats, down from an estimate of 2,600 in 2014 and 3,000 in 2013.
In 2010, there were an estimated 3,000 to 4,600 female martens in New Brunswick.
The New Brunswick moose herd numbered 31,819 animals strong in 2015, up from 25,916 in 2010.
The number of whitetail deer in the province for 2014 was 74,338 animals, up from 59,448 in 2010.
The latest available estimates of black bear show approximately 11,189 animals in the province as of 2013.
The original RTI did not include data for beaver, otter, weasel, fox, fishers, coyote or coyote hybrids.
